results.title: If***
results.creator_credit: Lindsay Anderson, Michael Medwin, Memorial and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: This film captures the particular ethos of a public school and the general flavour of any highly structured community, combining an allegorical thrust with a clear-eyed exploration of an essentially British institution. Constructed in 8 chapters introduced by titles in a Brechtian schema, a surrealistic edge (Anderson prefers ‘heightened reality’) is brought to events in the later sections as the line is blurred between fantasy and reality, an approach reflecting the influence of Zero de Conduite. Although conceived several years earlier, the timing of “If’s” release coinciding with the events of May 1968 ensured its success against the expectations of Paramount’s executives.

results.title: If you love this planet
results.creator_credit: Terri Nash, Edward Le Lorrain, Kathleen Shannon and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This film records a lecture given to students by outspoken nuclear critic, Dr. Helen Caldicott, president of Physicians for Social Responsibility in the United States. Her message is clear: disarmament cannot be postponed. Archival film footage of the bombing of Hiroshima and images of its survivors seven months after the attack heighten the urgency of her message: namely, that unless we shake off our indifference and work to prevent nuclear war, we stand a slim chance of surviving the 20th century.

results.title: If We Don't, Remember Me
results.brief_description:
IWDRM was a blog of animated movie stills active from 2010 to 2015.

A video installation was shown in exhibitions at the Contemporary Arts Museum (Houston, TX), &FOAM (Amsterdam) and The Event (Birmingham).

results.title: If we don't go, we'll never know, will we?
results.creator_credit: Constance Bernstein, Russell Toose and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chequerboard”.
The Gordons, with their four children, are migrating from England to australia. This film interviews the Gordons in England and hears of their hopes and dreams. It then spends the first six months in Australia with the family to find out the reality. Reporters: Richard Oxenburgh, Robert Higson.

group_siblings.title: My brown skin baby, they take 'im away

results.title: If these walls could talk
results.creator_credit: Cher, Nancy Savoca and Home Box Office
results.brief_description: Three short films made for television, centred around the theme of women and abortion, set over three decades with each story reflecting changing social conditions for women. “1952”: Claire (Demi Moore), a pregnant young war widow, is devastated by her lack of choices and unsympathetic views of her colleagues and family. After failing to induce a miscarriage Claire searches for an illegal abortionist, with dire consequences. “1974”: A mother of four’s unplanned pregnancy threatens her newly found emancipation at college. “1996”: University student Chris (Anne Heche) is pregnant to a professor who has no interest in her or the baby. Whilst Chris is deciding whether to keep the baby she is besieged by anti-abortionists at a clinic and faces being slighted by her moralising best friend. Chris becomes increasingly despondent as she tries to make a decision about her future. Although these three short films are melodramatic and fairly straightforward in both their presentation and dramatisation, the issues that they remark upon are compelling, particularly within the context of each decades shifting social mores and attitudes toward women’s issues.

results.title: If I should fall from grace: the Shane MacGowan story
results.creator_credit: Sarah Share, Emdee 2000 Productions, Irish Film Board and TG4
results.brief_description: This Irish documentary plots the legendary musician Shane MacGowan’s rise to fame, and infamy, as the lead singer of Irish band “The Pogues” and his subsequent dismissal. Along with footage of live performances, video clips and an extended contemporary interview with MacGowan, this documentary also contains illuminating discussions with friends, family, colleagues, and fellow musicians Nick Cave, Philip Chevron, and Paul Simonon from “The Clash”. Extensive footage from MacGowan’s past, in particular performances from the 1970s and 80s, presents an artist influenced by the traditions of Irish music and song, but also spurred on by the anti-establishment ethos and damaging excesses of the Punk Rock movement. Sarah Share presents an honest and compelling portrait of an evidently talented musician whose addiction to drugs and alcohol has seriously impeded his ambition and ability to maintain stability, in life and in his art. Songs featured include: Paddy public enemy No 1, If I should fall from grace with God, Infatuation, Gabrielle, Waxie’s dargle, Streams of whiskey, Dirty old town, The Irish rover, Fiesta, A Rainy night in Soho, Fairytale in New York, White city, Summer in Siam, Song with no name, That woman’s got me drinking, Haunted and Lonesome highway.

results.title: Idomeneo
results.creator_credit: Christopher Swann, Trevor Nunn, BBC-TV, Glyndebourne and RM Arts
results.brief_description: Heroic drama in three acts with music by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, libretto by Abbate Varesco, and performance by the Glyndebourne Chorus (Chorus Director - Jane Glover) and the London Philharmonic Orchestra (Leader - David Nolan) conducted by Bernard Haitink. This made for television production stars Philip Langridge (Idomeneo), Yvonne Kenny (Ilia), Jerry Hadley (Idamante), Carol Vaness (Electra), Thomas Hensley (Arbace) and Anthony Roden (High Priest). This is director Trevor Nunn’s debut into opera but recent credits include “Cats” and “The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby”.
